title: Sale price vs list price of houses

content.description: The least-squares regression line <math alttext="S hat, equals 0.5 plus 1.1 times L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1.1</mn><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> models the relationship between the listing price and the actual sales price of 12 houses, with both amounts given in hundred-thousands of dollars. Let <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the listing price and <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the sales price.
content.question: Which of the following is the best interpretation of the slope of the regression line?

choices.label: For each hundred-thousand-dollar increase in the listing price, the sales price will increase by $1.1.
For each hundred-thousand-dollar increase in the listing price, the sales price will increase by $110,000.
For each hundred-thousand-dollar increase in the listing price, the sales price will decrease by $110,000.
For each hundred-thousand-dollar increase in the listing price, the sales price is predicted to increase by $1.1.
For each hundred-thousand-dollar increase in the listing price, the sales price is predicted to increase by $110,000.

content.answer: For each hundred-thousand-dollar increase in the listing price, the sales price is predicted to increase by $110,000.

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
